  • And the defaulters will have to make disclosure within one working day from the date of default at the first instance of default. Excellent. Aug 05, 2017
  • So, it's more stringent than provisioning requirements prescribed by RBI. And even partial non payment on due date constitutes default. Aug 05, 2017
  • Applies to all debt including bank debt. Also ‘Default’ means non-payment of interest or principal amount in full on the pre-agreed date. Aug 05, 2017
  • New SEBI requirement (https://t.co/sXkGq6Se0W) for disclosure on defaults is welcome because it's wide and stringent. Aug 05, 2017

  • @Sanjay__Bakshi In Munger terminology, classical conditioning is Pavlovian Mis-association while operant conditioning is about incentives. Sep 04, 2016

  • @ONLYNITIN Look what happened to Valeant. And that's just one recent example. Sep 04, 2016
  • @ONLYNITIN No. The focus should be on creating wealth, not near term earnings. Often, these objectives conflict with each other. Sep 04, 2016

  • @adatar If incentives r linked to near term earnings instead of long-term value there will be behavior that'll maximise former & hurt latter Sep 04, 2016
  • And so it's wrong to blame the people. It's just bad system design to blame. Sep 04, 2016

  • @ashukartik4778 Not unless you are a registered student at MDI. Sep 15, 2015
  • @barathmukhi Yes. Sep 14, 2015
  • @barathmukhi When it comes to valuation, using pretax earnings can b questioned but for evaluating quality using pretax numbers makes sense. Sep 14, 2015
  • @barathmukhi So the durability of the spread between Pretax ROE and pretax AAA bond yield is far more important than the spread itself. Sep 14, 2015
  • @barathmukhi And the converse is also true. Many high ROE businesses at present will have much poorer profitability in the future. Sep 14, 2015
  • @barathmukhi Also keep in mind this is only a heuristic. Many businesses don't earn high ROE's now but might do so in future. Sep 14, 2015
  • @barathmukhi The ROE I referred to should be based on owner earnings and not reported earnings. Sep 14, 2015
  • @barathmukhi Comparing pre-tax ROE (without use of excessive leverage) with pre-tax AAA bond yield is a good heuristic to determine quality. Sep 14, 2015

  • @IVivekPandey Graham's method for capitalizing rent & other fixed charges 2 arrive at true indebtedness of a business http://t.co/enBKzSLFpa Aug 06, 2015
  • @IVivekPandey No view on stock. I am only referring to the correct treatment of rent on its P&L for analysing the business. Aug 06, 2015
  • @IVivekPandey He treated fixed costs like rent & lease payments as fixed charges, just like interest on debt & that's the correct treatment. Aug 06, 2015
  • @IVivekPandey That's what he used the term "fixed charges cover" instead of "interest cover." He knew interest can be camouflaged as rent Aug 06, 2015
  • @IVivekPandey Ben graham was very careful about these things. He never went by labels. Rather he focused on economic substance. Aug 06, 2015
  • @IVivekPandey Interest is nothing but rent on other ppl's money. If I see a lot of rent in a P&L, I find it useful 2 think of it as interest Aug 06, 2015

  • @Ameya_Kanetkar If you do, I will give you a pet name: Ameya-The man with a hammer. 😀 good night now. Jul 20, 2015
  • @Ameya_Kanetkar Never ever think about economics with also thinking about psychology. Jul 20, 2015
  • @Ameya_Kanetkar Or the global car manufacturing industry. Jul 20, 2015
  • @Ameya_Kanetkar Even, to some extent, fracking industry in the US. Jul 20, 2015
  • @Ameya_Kanetkar See what's happening in India's ecommerce space. Or global oil industry Jul 20, 2015
  • @Ameya_Kanetkar Envy, ego, animal spirits, loss aversion, prisoners' dilemma, overconfidence (the other fellow will blink first), sunk costs Jul 20, 2015
  • @Ameya_Kanetkar Economics should be grateful to psychology. It should tell her: "You complete me." Jul 20, 2015
  • @Ameya_Kanetkar So the rational man models from economics have utility only if you combine them with foolish man models from psychology. Jul 20, 2015
  • @Ameya_Kanetkar Economic models make predictions based on the assumption that humans r rational. Psychology shows sometimes aren't. Jul 20, 2015
  • @Ameya_Kanetkar Economics says when prices fall to a certain level business should shut down.But it doesn't.Psychology tells u why it didn't Jul 20, 2015
  • @PradeepKanwar Very cool collection. Had not seen them earlier. Thanks. @Vamsee9002 Jul 20, 2015
  • @Vamsee9002 Gresham's law http://t.co/NtD0CV39RB should be taught at every course in competitive strategy. Jul 20, 2015
  • @Vamsee9002 Leave Jul 20, 2015
  • @Vamsee9002 A conglomerate that behaves like a lemming (which many do) won't help. What u need is a very different kind of corporate culture Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo I don't know. Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo Economics is incomplete without psychology. Ideas like "shut down point" in economics are horribly incomplete sans psychology. Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo Yes of course.I don't think a strong balance sheet can compensate 4 crazy competitive behaviour backed by unlimited capital. Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo And the damn cycle refuses to turn for a long long time for the reason I mentioned above. Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo And they get so confident (physics envy) that they build large, leveraged positions in the belief that cycle is about to turn. Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo People just take past cycles and extrapolate them. So if shipping cycles in the past have lasted x years,next one will too will Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo Whenever u see a lot of dumb competition backed by almost unlimited supply of dumber money, b very careful about mean reversion Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo And these games of prisoners' dilemma backed by dumb money get prolonged and u get 20 year low prices, then 30 year low prices. Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo But the other guy has dumb money too. And the industry capacity just doesn't shrink. So how the hell will the mean revert? Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo Access to dumb money enables them to have the privilege of hoping that the other fellow will die and things will REVERT BACK Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo But u know something? Often they don't because they get stupid money which keeps them alive even though they should die. Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo Under conditions of rational behaviour by industry participants who respect Tobin's Q & shut down when it makes economic sense. Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo And the extreme leverage was used because of overconfidence in the idea of mean reversion as if it was the law of gravitation. Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo And then they assume that the anomaly WILL disappear by a certain time. And then they die. Like LTCM Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo But some people behave as if they are laws. They become supremely confident. They find an "anomaly". Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo There are only "tendencies" in social science. No laws which are SUPPOSED to be adhered to. Jul 20, 2015
  • @vineetmaloo The problem is with your usage of the word "suppose". That IS the problem my friend. This is social science not physics. 😊 Jul 20, 2015

  • @letsgrowmoney Do you see a pattern from a collection of images of railway platforms? I see a pattern. @sureshpprabhu Jul 18, 2015
  • @letsgrowmoney So the way to notice change is to go deeper and look for evidence of change.Then decide if there's a pattern. @sureshpprabhu Jul 18, 2015
  • @letsgrowmoney By the time the change shows up in consolidated numbers, it would be too late for you to act. @sureshpprabhu Jul 18, 2015
  • @letsgrowmoney If you only look at aggregate data you will fail to notice important changes. @sureshpprabhu Jul 18, 2015
  • @letsgrowmoney How should you notice change? By looking specifically for evidence of change or looking at aggregate data? @sureshpprabhu Jul 18, 2015
  • @letsgrowmoney At least recognise there is a change in the air. Slow change tends to go unnoticed, so notice it. @sureshpprabhu @shyamsek Jul 18, 2015
  • @letsgrowmoney Stop overdosing on Taleb please. Earlier, everything filthy. Now there is evidence of change. Appreciate it. @sureshpprabhu Jul 18, 2015
  • Assignment: Go to @sureshpprabhu and see the images of railway platforms he has been retweeting-images taken by users, not a PR firm. Do it. Jul 18, 2015
  • Advice to India's real estate developers on how to reduce inventory. @ravirpurohit :-) http://t.co/lFgEGyV5vz Jul 18, 2015

  • @scode_snn Premortems may reduce the probability of postmortems. For that reason alone, they are worth doing, no? Jul 18, 2015

  • Good night folks. Will discuss something else tomorrow. Jul 17, 2015
  • @ambergupta73 It's binary. Like virginity. You are either a Virgin or you are not. No such thing as 58% Virgin. 😆 Jul 17, 2015
  • @ambergupta73 Yes. But since I like concentrated portfolios for me Premortems are more like Go/No Go decision points. Jul 17, 2015
  • @mihir23192 Yah I did a couple of workshops. And here is the best book I read on the subject: http://t.co/9aGAdQknLV Jul 17, 2015
  • @ambergupta73 And Two: if I go ahead what to watch out for. @Vamsee9002 Jul 17, 2015
  • @ambergupta73 For me, mostly premortems serve two purposes. One: Go/No Go @Vamsee9002 Jul 17, 2015
  • @ambergupta73 Some ppl will deal with this issue in position sizing. I am not a big fan of that approach. Vamsee9002 Jul 17, 2015
  • @ambergupta73 What next depends on other choices you may have. You don't have to do this if you have a better choice. @Vamsee9002 Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha Premortems help calibration of confidence levels.If something keeps going wrong 4 reasons u didn't envisage,u have a problem. Jul 17, 2015
  • @Vamsee9002 It happened in 1 case. But the sons took over & they get along. But in another parallel universe it cud have gone the other way. Jul 17, 2015
  • @mihir23192 How could you not be going right by doing premortems? Of course you are going right. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha The functional equivalent of Superexcited Tata Steel just before winning the hand of Princess Corus is there in all of us. Jul 17, 2015
  • @Sanjay__Bakshi Focus on 3 weakest links. A chain is only as strong as its weakest link. I wrote this many years ago: http://t.co/kN7BY0g3k1 Jul 17, 2015
  • @mihir23192 Sure. If I am thinking of investing in an MNC's Indian sub, 1 premortem item is possibility of screwing of minority investors. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha But that's irrelevant. A premortem could have saved Tata Steel. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha That's compounding one mistake over another. And the outcome is a disaster in one case and not too bad in the other one. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha And they got into auctions. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha In both cases they were funded with debt in forex. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha Both are good examples of bad process. In both cases the deals were very large in relation to size of acquirers. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha My favourite example here is Tata Steel's acquisition of Corus and Tata Motor's acquisition of JLR. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha So if IPOD project if it failed would have sunk Apple that was bad process regardless of outcome. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha Making small mistakes is a part of a good process. What you don't want to see is the prevalence of big mistakes. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha One advantage is that if some shit does happen later you wud know if it was because of something u anticipated or not. Jul 17, 2015
  • @harbeerchadha It's just a moment of reflection before making big decisions. Shit happens. Jul 17, 2015
  • @Vamsee9002 In a tech hardware company it could be obsolescence. In a regulated business it could be change in regulations Jul 17, 2015
  • @Vamsee9002 For example in a family run business it could b death of the founder. In a business with 1 customer it cud be concentration risk Jul 17, 2015
  • @Vamsee9002 By limiting yourself to 3 things that can go wrong, you force urself to think of 3 big risks. Jul 17, 2015
  • @Vamsee9002 If you can come up with 3 things that cud go wrong, u have a moment to reflect and ask: Do I have to do this? Jul 17, 2015
  • @Sanjay__Bakshi When u think of risks, u think of many things. But when u do Premortems, u focus on weakest links in the investment thesis. Jul 17, 2015
  • @Sanjay__Bakshi Jul 17, 2015
  • @Sanjay__Bakshi I think they are especially helpful if you have a concentrated portfolio. Jul 17, 2015
  • @Sanjay__Bakshi Premortems come just before u make the decision. They r like an additional safety valve as they force u 2 pause and reflect. Jul 17, 2015
